RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduação em Ciências Econômicas pela Universidade Federal da Bahia (2011), mestrado em Economia - Universidad Carlos III de Madrid (2015) e doutorado em Economia - Universidad Carlos III de Madrid (2019). Atualmente é professor assistente - Insper Instituto de Ensino e Pesquisa. Tem experiência na área de Economia, com ênfase em Métodos e Modelos Matemáticos, Econométricos e Estatísticos
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: graduation at Ciências Econômicas from Universidade Federal da Bahia (2011) and master's at Economia from Universidad Carlos III de Madrid (2015). Has experience in Economics, focusing on Mathematical, Econometrical and Statistical Methods and Models

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Minimum Wage, Business Dynamism and the Life Cycle of Firms
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This paper studies the effects of the minimum wage on the life cycle of firms. Using matched employer-employee and census data, I analyze the large increase in the federal minimum wage in Brazil between 1999 and 2010. Based on a difference-in-differences approach exploiting exposure of both firms and local labor markets to the minimum wage policy, I find that an increase in the minimum wage: (i) decreases the growth rates of small and young establishments, and (ii) increases the growth rates of old and large establishments. Moreover, establishment exit in affected regions increased following the increase of the minimum wage, although I found no effect on the entry of new firms. While traditional monopsony models cannot account for this result, a neoclassical monopsonistic model where firms face financial frictions can rationalize this finding.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: This paper studies the effects of the minimum wage on the life cycle of firms. Using matched employer-employee and census data, I analyze the large increase in the federal minimum wage in Brazil between 1999 and 2010. Based on a difference-in-differences approach exploiting exposure of both firms and local labor markets to the minimum wage policy, I find that an increase in the minimum wage: (i) decreases the growth rates of small and young establishments, and (ii) increases the growth rates of old and large establishments. Moreover, establishment exit in affected regions increased following the increase of the minimum wage, although I found no effect on the entry of new firms. While traditional monopsony models cannot account for this result, a neoclassical monopsonistic model where firms face financial frictions can rationalize this finding.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Minimum Wage, Business Dynamism and the Life Cycle of Firms
